reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to develop chest tightness, shortness of breath, and occasional palpitations after exertion 6 months ago. The attacks lasted about 30 minutes and resolved spontaneously, with intermittent attacks. Symptoms have worsened in the past week, accompanied by fatigue and decreased activity tolerance. There was no syncope, nausea, vomiting, or precordial pain. The electrocardiogram from another hospital showed atrial fibrillation, and the ejection fraction on cardiac color Doppler ultrasound was 35%. The patient was given coronary enlargement, anti-platelet, lipid-lowering and anti-heart failure treatments in the outpatient clinic, but the symptoms were not relieved, so he was admitted to the hospital. There was no fever, cough, sputum production, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or lower limb edema. His diet was normal, his bowel movements were normal, and there was no significant change in his weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- blood test
  -NT-ProBNP: 404.20pg/mL
- Echocardiography
  - Inner diameter of left atrium: 58×50mm
  - Right chamber inner diameter: 51×45mm
  - Left ventricular end diastolic diameter: 58mm
  - Mitral and tricuspid regurgitation: trace-mild
  - Aortic valve degeneration
  - Reduced left ventricular diastolic function
  - Decreased overall left ventricular systolic function (ejection fraction EF: 34%)
- Holter electrocardiogram
  - Ectopic rhythm
  - Atrial fibrillation with fast ventricular rate (average heart rate 105 beats/min)
  - T wave changes
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy and cardiac insufficiency (cardiac function class II)
2. Cardiac arrhythmia atrial fibrillation
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has a long-term history of smoking and drinking, and has symptoms such as chest tightness and shortness of breath. The ejection fraction on cardiac color ultrasound is 35%.
2. The physical examination revealed that the heart rhythm was absolutely irregular and the heart sounds varied in intensity.
3. The patient has risk factors such as age, drinking and smoking, and has chest tightness and shortness of breath after activity, so coronary heart disease cannot be ruled out.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, treatment was given to reduce cardiac pre- and post-load, including recombinant human natriuretic peptide, furosemide, spironolactone, sacubitril-valsartan, dapagliflozin, metoprolol succinate, aspirin, clopidogrel, and rivar Shaban. Coronary CTA showed no stenotic lesions. Consider alcoholic cardiomyopathy, discontinue dual anti-drug therapy, and continue anti-heart failure treatment. The symptoms were relieved after 8 days. Before discharge, he was educated to stop drinking and take medicine as prescribed by the doctor. A follow-up cardiac ultrasound 3 months later showed that the EF had increased to 54%, and alcoholic cardiomyopathy was diagnosed.

Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, atrial fibrillation, and valvular heart disease

(3) Elevated NT-ProBNP level indicating heart failure

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medications to control atrial fibrillation, reduce heart rate, and improve heart's pumping function
(2) Lifestyle changes, including reducing alcohol consumption and increasing physical activity levels
(3) Cardiac catheterization to determine the extent of coronary artery disease and identify other potential causes of heart failure

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient was found to have bilateral thyroid masses through color ultrasound one year ago, with the left side being larger and painless. There were no other symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. Recently, the mass on the left side of the neck has increased. Color ultrasound showed that the left lobe of the thyroid gland is occupying space, which is considered malignant. The cervical lymph nodes are swollen and partially calcified. The neck mass was punctured and dark red fluid was aspirated, and a biopsy was recommended. The patient's general condition is good and there is no obvious weight loss.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Color ultrasound examination
  - Space-occupying left thyroid lobe with sandy calcification, TI-RADS category IV C
  - Multiple swollen lymph nodes on the left side of the neck with some calcifications
  - Right thyroid lobe nodule, TI-RADS category III
- Fine needle aspiration
  - 2 ml of dark red liquid was aspirated, and scattered epithelial cells were seen. The possibility of thyroid follicular epithelium was considered, and nuclear grooves were visible in some parts.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Left thyroid gland cancer (T2N1M0), right benign nodule.
reference_diagnosis.basis: Based on the medical history, physical examination and auxiliary examination results, it is considered that the left lobe of the thyroid gland may be malignant and the right lobe nodule may be benign. Intraoperative rapid pathology showed thyroid cancer on the left side and no clear tumor tissue on the right side. Paraffin pathology further confirmed that the left thyroid gland had ovarian cancer, with a mass size of 2cm × 2cm × 1cm, and tumor tissue metastasis in the left central area and cervical lymph nodes. The right thyroid gland is an adenoma.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient completed relevant examinations, including blood routine, thyroid function, liver and kidney function, blood sugar, electrolytes, coagulation function, electrocardiogram, chest X-ray, etc. No abnormalities were found. CT neck showed space occupying the left lobe of the thyroid gland and enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. Preoperative preparation was sufficient, and left thyroid lobe + isthmus resection + right subtotal thyroidectomy was performed. The patient recovered well after the operation and was given fluids, electrolytes and hemostatic treatment. The sutures were removed and discharged after 10 days of hospitalization.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Painless thyroid mass on the left side for about a year, with gradual growth
(2) Recent increase in size of the mass over the past few months

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Color ultrasound: bilateral thyroid masses, with the left side being larger; recent ultrasound showed the left lobe of the thyroid gland occupying space, considered malignant; cervical lymph nodes are also swollen and partially calcified
(2) Fine-needle aspiration biopsy: scattered epithelial cells seen, possibility of thyroid follicular epithelium considered, nuclear grooves visible in some parts
(3) Thyroid function tests: no abnormalities
(4) Calcitonin level test: no abnormalities
(5) Neck CT scan: no abnormalities
(6) Physical examination: palpable 2.0cm x 1cm firm mass on the left side of the neck, smooth surface, no tenderness, movable; left cervical lymph nodes enlarged, slightly tender, limited mobility

#Diagnosis#
Thyroid cancer (likely papillary thyroid carcinoma)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Ultrasound findings of a space-occupying lesion with sandy calcification in the left thyroid lobe, classified as TI-RADS category IV C, indicating high suspicion of malignancy
(2) Fine-needle aspiration biopsy results suggesting thyroid follicular epithelium with nuclear grooves, consistent with thyroid cancer
(3) Physical examination findings of a palpable mass and enlarged lymph nodes

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Surgical biopsy of the left thyroid lobe to obtain a definitive diagnosis
(2) Lymph node dissection on the left side of the neck to remove affected lymph nodes

reference_diagnosis.basis:

2. Physical examination revealed mild upper abdominal tenderness without rebound tenderness.
3. Routine blood test showed normal white blood cell count and elevated neutrophil ratio.
4. Dyslipidemia and significantly elevated blood amylase.

After 5 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms improved significantly, and his blood amylase dropped to 46U/L, and he was subsequently discharged.

#Symptoms#

(4) No changes in stool or urine

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Ultrasound of the upper abdomen: cholecystitis, mild dilation of the common bile duct, gallbladder stones (sand-like), splenic cystic echo, and bilateral renal cysts
(2) Complete Blood Count (CBC): White blood cell count 7.2*10^9/L, Neutrophil ratio 71.3%
(3) Blood Chemistry: No abnormalities

#Diagnosis#
Acute Cholecystitis likely caused by a gallstone blocking the cystic duct

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Ultrasound findings of cholecystitis, gallbladder stones, and mild dilation of the common bile duct
(2) Consistent symptoms of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting
(3) Elevated white blood cell count and neutrophil ratio suggesting an inflammatory response

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Hospitalization for further management and treatment
(2) Supportive care, including fluids and pain management, to help manage symptoms
(3) Surgical consultation to discuss the possibility of a cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder)

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed fever after catching cold due to exertion, with the highest temperature reaching 39°C, accompanied by fatigue, myalgia, cough, and sputum production. She was treated with cephalosporin antibiotics at a local clinic, but her symptoms were not relieved. The condition gradually worsened, with chest tightness, shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. Outpatient chest CT showed bilateral lung infection and nodular lesions, and he was subsequently admitted to the hospital.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Sheep brucellosis
2. Tuberculosis and lung infection
3. Liver damage
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Personal history: Engaged in sheep slaughtering and selling sheep braised products.
2. Symptoms: Fever, fatigue for more than 10 days, shortness of breath, and dyspnea for 5 days.
3. Physical signs: clear mind, poor energy, thick breath sounds in both lungs, and phlegm sounds.
4. Auxiliary examination: ESR 72mm/h, abnormal liver function, growth of Brucella in blood culture, positive tuberculosis gamma interferon release test, chest CT showed bilateral lung infection and nodular lesions.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient received anti-infective treatment, phlegm-reducing treatment, hepatoprotective treatment and nutritional support treatment. The condition did not improve, and brucellosis was considered. Blood culture and antibody tests were both positive. After one week of treatment, his condition did not improve. Further examination revealed that the tuberculosis gamma interferon release test was positive, and he was diagnosed as pulmonary tuberculosis infection. After additional treatment with anti-tuberculosis drugs, the body temperature dropped, the erythrocyte sedimentation rate dropped, and the patient was discharged after his condition became stable.

#Treatment Plan#

Abnormal liver function was found during admission examination.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Chest tightness and cough for 1 week
(2) Yellowish eyes and skin, yellow urine, fatigue, and poor appetite for 3 days
(3) Shortness of breath, especially with exertion
(4) Palpitations
(5) Abdominal discomfort, mostly in the upper right quadrant
(6) Pale and clay-colored stools
(7) Weight loss

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Physical examination: yellow discoloration of skin and mucous membranes, mild tenderness in the liver area
(2) Laboratory tests:
	* White blood cell count: slightly elevated
	* Liver function tests:
		+ ALT: 693.59 U/L
		+ AST: 555.87 U/L
		+ TBIL: 43.57 μmol/L
(3) Ultrasound examination:
	* Liver: slightly enlarged, nodular surface
	* Gallbladder: normal size and shape

#Diagnosis#
Hepatitis (likely viral or autoimmune)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST) and total bilirubin (TBIL) indicating liver damage or inflammation
(2) Yellow discoloration of skin and mucous membranes, and dark urine suggesting bilirubin accumulation
(3) Mild tenderness in the liver area and nodular surface on ultrasound examination suggesting liver disease
(4) Exclusion of other possible causes of symptoms, such as gallstone or bile duct obstruction, based on ultrasound examination

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Supportive care: medication to manage fatigue and abdominal discomfort
(2) Further testing: viral hepatitis panel, autoimmune markers, and ERCP to evaluate bile ducts
(3) Treatment of underlying cause: antiviral therapy if viral hepatitis, immunosuppressive therapy if autoimmune hepatitis, and liver transplantation if liver cirrhosis
(4) Monitoring of liver function and symptoms to adjust treatment plan as needed

After antiviral and intracranial pressure-lowering treatment, his consciousness returned to clarity, but he had no memory of the attack and had headache symptoms. - Cerebrospinal fluid examination
  - Pressure: 140mmH2O

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Low-grade glioma
reference_diagnosis.basis:

reference_diagnosis.treatment: Improve relevant examinations, neurosurgery consultation, and consider low-grade glioma. reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient accidentally discovered bilateral neck masses one month ago, which were about the size of a walnut. He did not feel any difficulty breathing or swallowing, and there was no foreign body sensation in the anterior neck or neck edema. There were no symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, such as heat intolerance, sweating, polyphagia, hunger, irritability, poor appetite, weight loss, hoarseness, or ptosis. His living habits such as diet, sleep, and urination were normal. He had not received any treatment. Color Doppler ultrasound examination at an external hospital showed mixed nodules and internal cystic nodules in both lobes of the thyroid gland, and no abnormalities were found in the cervical lymph nodes. The patient came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. The outpatient diagnosis was "bilateral thyroid tumors" and he was admitted to the hospital.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
Thyroid color ultrasound:
- Mixed nodules in both thyroid lobes, TI-RADS classification: Category 3
- Intrathyroid cystic nodule, TI-RADS classification: Category 2
- No obvious abnormal lymph nodes were found on both sides of the neck
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Bilateral nodular goiter
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
reference_diagnosis.basis: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with a thyroid tumor for more than a month. Physical examination revealed bilateral thyroid tumors, approximately 3.5cm × 3.0cm in size, with clear boundaries, smooth surface, medium texture, and no tenderness. They could move up and down with swallowing, and no vascular murmur was heard.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient completed relevant examinations after admission and found no contraindications to surgery. Bilateral subtotal thyroidectomy was performed under cervical plexus block anesthesia. Shortness of breath, cyanosis, increased heart rate, and chest X-ray showed pulmonary edema after surgery. Consider ARDS, perform endotracheal intubation immediately, assist ventilation, and administer dopamine, albumin, plasma, adrenocortical hormones, and antibiotics. His condition stabilized after 24 hours, and he recovered and was discharged from the hospital half a month later.

(4) No changes in energy levels, appetite, or sleep patterns

#Auxiliary Examinations#

(3) FNAB: no abnormal findings
(4) Thyroid scintigraphy: no abnormal findings
(5) Neck CT scan: not performed

#Diagnosis#
Benign thyroid nodules

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Physical examination and ultrasound findings of bilateral thyroid masses and nodules
(2) FNAB result showing no abnormal findings
(3) Thyroid scintigraphy result showing no abnormal functional activity
(4) Lack of symptoms and signs of thyroid dysfunction or malignancy

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Regular follow-up appointments to monitor the size and growth of the thyroid nodules
(2) Repeat ultrasound examination in 6-12 months to assess any changes in the nodules
(3) Lifestyle recommendations to help manage thyroid health, such as maintaining a healthy diet, staying hydrated, and managing stress

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient reported that he began to have pain in the joints of his limbs, especially his knees and shoulder joints, 1 week ago. He was accompanied by fatigue, increased stool frequency, yellow stools and rotten texture. During this period, there were no symptoms such as cough, sputum, chest tightness and chest pain, but there was low-grade fever. No frequency of urination, urgency of urination or painful urination. Liver function tests at the local hospital were abnormal, ALT and AST were elevated, and albumin was reduced. Oral medication was tried but the effect was not good. The patient's spirit and sleep were normal, his weight change was unknown, and he had no history of exposure to COVID-19. After admission, the nucleic acid screening test for COVID-19 was negative.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood biochemistry test
  - ALT: 196.81 U/L
  - AST: 239.46 U/L
  - Albumin: 34.46 g/L
- Film degree exam
  - Chest X-ray: No abnormality
  - CT: liver cirrhosis, left renal cyst, prostate calcification
- Other checks
  - Coagulation function: prothrombin time 14.5 seconds, thrombin time 17.2 seconds
  - Liver function: alanine aminotransferase 188.00 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase 228.00 U/L, total bilirubin 36.66 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 12.87 μmol/L, indirect bilirubin 23.79 μmol/L, total bile acid 24.50 μmol/L, adenosine deaminase 31.80 U/L
  - Immunological examination: rheumatoid factor 13.70 IU/ml, anti-streptolysin O 14.70 IU/ml, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody 7.90 U/ml
  - Fibrosis indicators: hyaluronidase 634.516 ng/mL, type IV collagen 175.023 ng/mL
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Cirrhosis (unknown cause)
2. Hypoproteinemia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Male, 63 years old, with mild scleral jaundice, mild upper abdominal tenderness, no rebound tenderness, liver and spleen below the ribs, normal bowel sounds, and mild edema in both lower limbs.
2. Blood biochemical tests showed elevated ALT and AST, and decreased albumin.
3. Imaging examination suggests liver cirrhosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent comprehensive examination and treatment, including liver function protection, anti-inflammation, and albumin supplementation. After 8 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms were relieved.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Recurrent limb joint pain, mainly in knees and shoulders
(2) Fatigue
(3) Increased stool frequency
(4) Abnormal liver function
(5) Yellow stools with a rotten texture
(6) Abdominal pain, mainly in the right upper quadrant, worsened after eating

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Blood tests: elevated ALT and AST, reduced albumin
(2) Ultrasound: liver cirrhosis, left kidney cyst, prostate calcification
(3) CT: liver cirrhosis
(4) Liver function tests: elevated total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, and total bile acid

#Diagnosis#
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) with liver cirrhosis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Elevated liver enzymes and abnormal liver function tests
(2) Ultrasound and CT findings of liver cirrhosis
(3) Exclusion of other possible causes of liver damage, such as viral hepatitis and autoimmune liver disease

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Stop taking painkillers to avoid further liver damage
(2) Lifestyle modifications: weight loss, healthy diet, regular exercise
(3) Monitor liver function and adjust treatment plan as needed
(4) Consider further testing, such as a liver biopsy, if necessary

reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, he was given acid-suppressing, stomach-protecting, anti-inflammatory, and hypoglycemic treatments. Complete electrocardiogram, blood routine, blood biochemistry, tumor markers, chest CT, abdominal CT, gastrointestinal endoscopy and other examinations. Chest CT and whole-abdominal CT showed high-density shadows in both lungs, but no other abnormalities were found. Gastroscopy revealed esophageal ulcers and proliferative bulges in the gastric antrum mucosa, but no abnormalities were found in colonoscopy. The patient later developed nausea, vomiting, and edema of both lower limbs. A reexamination of liver function revealed hypoalbuminemia, and renal function examination revealed renal insufficiency. After consultation with the nephrology department, it was recommended to complete the detection of urinary Binder protein and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. The patient was later transferred to a higher-level hospital for treatment and was diagnosed with ANCA-associated vasculitis.

#Symptoms#

#Auxiliary Examinations#

#Diagnosis#
Pulmonary infection or exacerbation of bronchiectasis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms of coughing and coughing up white sputum, along with the Chest CT results showing multiple high-density shadows in both lungs, suggest a pulmonary infection or exacerbation of bronchiectasis.
(2) The patient's upper abdominal pain and loss of appetite may be related to the pulmonary infection or exacerbation of bronchiectasis, possibly due to referred pain or systemic inflammation.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antibiotic therapy to treat the pulmonary infection or exacerbation of bronchiectasis
(2) Symptomatic treatment for the upper abdominal pain and loss of appetite, such as antacids or pain relief medications
(3) Follow-up Chest CT or other imaging tests to monitor the patient's response to treatment and assess for any complications or underlying conditions.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Acute cholecystitis, gallbladder stones, dyslipidemia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Abdominal pain for 4 days, upper abdominal cramping and then spread to the whole abdomen.
2. Past history of gallbladder stones.
3. Auxiliary examinations showed elevated C-reactive protein, mildly elevated amylase and lipase, abnormal blood lipids, and ultrasound and CT showed gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
1. After thorough examination after admission, CRP was elevated, transaminases and bilirubin were normal, and ultrasound and CT showed gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis.
2. For treatment, a liquid diet, pantoprazole 20 mg once every two days for acid suppression, piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5 g every 12 hours for intravenous anti-infection, and fluid rehydration were given for 5 days.
3. The patient's abdominal pain is relieved and there is no nausea or vomiting. It is recommended that he and hepatobiliary surgery be further diagnosed and treated after discharge to evaluate the indications for cholecystectomy.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Abdominal pain for 4 days, starting as epigastric cramping after eating pineapple and fried meat, and then spreading to the entire abdomen
(2) Nausea, vomiting, and dizziness
(3) Worsening of pain after eating, especially fatty or greasy foods, and with movement
(4) Relief of pain when lying still

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Ultrasound: gallbladder stones
(2) Abdominal CT scan: gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis
(3) Laboratory tests:
	* White blood cell count: 6.99×10^9/L
	* Hemoglobin: 132g/L
	* Platelets: 229×10^9/L
	* Albumin: 39.50g/L
	* Amylase: 122.00U/L
	* Lipase: 315.00U/L

#Diagnosis#
Acute cholecystitis secondary to gallstones

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness, which are consistent with acute cholecystitis
(2) Ultrasound and abdominal CT scan results, which confirm the presence of gallstones and cholecystitis
(3) Elevated amylase and lipase levels, which suggest pancreatic enzyme elevation, often seen in acute cholecystitis

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Hospitalization for further management and observation
(2) Antibiotic therapy to treat the infection
(3) Fluid and electrolyte replacement to prevent dehydration
(4) Pain management to control abdominal pain
(5) Cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) to be considered as a definitive treatment option

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed weakness in both lower limbs 2 days ago. He can stand but needs support from family members to walk. He is accompanied by dizziness and nausea. His blood pressure was measured at 180/?mmHg. The dizziness was relieved after taking antihypertensive drugs. There was no numbness or abnormal sensation in the limbs. The muscle strength of both upper limbs was good. Normal, no speech disorder, normal bowel movements, no change in weight.

  - Cervical, thoracic and lumbar bone hyperplasia
- Central nervous system demyelinating disease spectrum (TBA+CBA):
  - cerebrospinal fluid AQP4 1:10, negative for MOG and GFAP
  - Serum AQP4 1:100, negative for MOG and GFAP
- Evoked potential:

  - Normal bilateral BAEP

  - Normal SEP of both upper limbs
- Cerebrospinal fluid examination:
  - Pressure 120mmH20
  - Colorless and transparent
  - Total number of cells 40x10^6/L
  - White blood cell count 40x10^6/L

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was female. She had a history of optic nerve atrophy leading to blindness in her left eye. The acute onset of the disease was weakness of both lower limbs. Auxiliary examination showed abnormal spinal MRI signals, abnormal evoked potentials, and positive AQP4 antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid, which met the diagnostic criteria for AQP4-lgG positive NMOSD.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After thorough examination after admission, the patient was diagnosed as NMOSD according to the "Chinese Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Treatment of Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Diseases (2021)". Treatment included intravenous methylprednisolone immunomodulation, step reduction, oral prednisone, potassium chloride, and methylprednisolone. Lazole and calcium carbonate D3 tablets are used to prevent hormonal side effects, and mycophenolate mofetil is used for immunosuppressive treatment. Symptoms were relieved, vital signs were stable, and discharge standards were met.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Weakness in both lower limbs for 2 days, requiring support to walk
(2) Dizziness and nausea, which improved with antihypertensive medication
(3) Constant weakness in both legs, with no numbness or abnormal sensations
(4) Decreased sensation to touch and pain on the right side below chest level 4

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Blood sugar: 7.8mmol/L
(2) Electrolyte: Magnesium 0.73↓mmol/L, the remainder is normal
(3) Whole spine MRI:
	* C3/4-C6/7 disc herniation
	* Abnormal signal in the spinal cord at T2-4 vertebral level, consider demyelinating disease
	* L3/4, L4/5 intervertebral disc bulge
	* Cervical, thoracic, and lumbar bone hyperplasia

#Diagnosis#
Demyelinating disease, likely multiple sclerosis, with possible spinal cord compression due to disc herniation and bone hyperplasia

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Abnormal signal in the spinal cord at T2-4 vertebral level on MRI, suggesting demyelination
(2) Decreased sensation to touch and pain on the right side below chest level 4, consistent with spinal cord involvement
(3) Weakness in both lower limbs, which may be related to spinal cord compression or demyelination

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Magnesium supplementation to address hypomagnesemia
(2) Spinal cord imaging with contrast to further evaluate the abnormal signal
(3) Neurological consultation to further evaluate and manage the demyelinating disease
(4) Physical therapy program to improve mobility and strength in the lower limbs

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient was hospitalized for treatment in April this year due to intracerebral hemorrhage in the right basal ganglia and thalamus. During the period, a head and chest CT scan revealed multiple brain and lung lesions. In June this year, he was admitted to a rehabilitation hospital due to a cough. Chest CT showed lung infection and lung mass, which improved after anti-infective treatment. He is currently hospitalized for further treatment. The patient currently presents with lethargy, occasional cough, sticky phlegm that is difficult to cough up, no nausea and vomiting, no abdominal pain and diarrhea, no significant weight loss, occasional constipation, indwelling gastric and urinary tubes, and restless sleep at night.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Head and chest CT
  - Cerebral hemorrhage in the right thalamus, breaking into the ventricular system, causing mass effect
  - Multiple cavity infarcts in the brain; brain atrophy, mild white matter degeneration
  - The lesions in the right lower lobe of the lung are enlarged, and space-occupying lesions may be
  - Right-sided pneumonia, left lung hypoventilation or small airway disease
  - Thickening of the pleura on both sides
  - Uneven thyroid density
  - Gallstone
- Blood gas analysis
  - pH 7.420
  - Carbon dioxide partial pressure 55.0mmHg↑
  - Oxygen partial pressure 59.0mmHg↓
  - Potassium ion 3.1mmol/L↓
  - Standard bicarbonate 32.5mmol/L↑
  - Glucose 6.4mmol/L↑
  - NT-proBNP (urgent) 2680.00pg/ml
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Severe pneumonia
2. Space-occupying lesions of the lungs
3. Type 2 respiratory failure
4. Hypertension grade 2 (high risk)
5. Type 2 diabetes
6. Coronary heart disease
7. Right thalamic hemorrhage
8. After PCI
9. Gallbladder stones
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Elderly male, cough and phlegm for more than 3 months
2. Symptoms: lethargy, occasional cough, sticky phlegm that is difficult to cough up, no nausea and vomiting, no abdominal pain and diarrhea, no significant weight loss, occasional constipation, indwelling gastric and urinary tubes, and restless night sleep
3. Physical examination: The chest is symmetrical, the breath sounds in both lungs are thick, a few crackles are heard, the heart rate is 80 beats/min, regular, and there is no pathological murmur. The abdomen is flat and soft, without tenderness, guarding, or rebound tenderness.
4. The auxiliary inspection results are as above
reference_diagnosis.treatment: Tracheal intubation, ventilator-assisted breathing, meropenem anti-infection, cough and phlegm relieving, antispasmodic and asthmatic, antihypertensive and hypoglycemic and other symptomatic treatments.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Cough and expectoration for more than three months
(2) Lethargy and fatigue
(3) Yellowish phlegm that is thick and sticky
(4) Cough worse at night, affecting sleep
(5) Occasional constipation and restless sleep

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest CT: Right basal ganglia hemorrhage, multiple cerebral infarcts, right lower lung lesion, right-sided pneumonia, left lung hypoventilation or small airway disease, bilateral pleural thickening, and thyroid density irregularity
(2) Blood gas analysis: Respiratory acidosis, elevated CO2 level, decreased oxygen level, decreased potassium level, elevated standard bicarbonate level, and elevated glucose level
(3) Physical examination: Fever, elevated blood pressure, muscle strength difference between left and right sides, and positive Pap sign on the left side

#Diagnosis#
Pneumonia or lung abscess, possibly related to underlying lung cancer or metastatic disease

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Chest CT findings of right lower lung lesion and right-sided pneumonia
(2) Blood gas analysis results indicating respiratory acidosis and decreased oxygen level
(3) Physical examination findings of fever, elevated blood pressure, and muscle strength difference between left and right sides

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Empiric antibiotics to manage symptoms and prevent further complications
(2) Supportive care, including oxygen therapy and fluids, to help manage symptoms and improve comfort
(3) Further testing, including sputum culture, bronchoscopy, and echocardiogram, to determine the underlying cause of symptoms and guide treatment decisions

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Lethargy for half a month, worsened with diarrhea and vomiting for the past two days
(2) Poor appetite, no interest in food or drinks, vomiting everything consumed
(3) Abdominal pain, muscle aches, especially in the back and legs
(4) Weakness, dizziness, trouble speaking clearly, and reacting slowly

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) CT examination: Multiple lacunar infarcts, subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy, senile brain changes, brainstem hypodensity considers infarction
(2) CT examination: Interstitial changes in both lungs, calcification lesions in right lung, sputum plug in right main bronchus, bilateral pleural localized thickening
(3) CT examination: Cystic lesions of the left kidney, prostate enlargement, wall thickening at the end of the right ileum and the beginning of the colon
(4) Blood oxygen saturation: SPO2 98%

#Diagnosis#
Cerebrovascular disease (lacunar infarcts, brainstem infarction) with respiratory infection and gastrointestinal complications

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) CT examination results showing multiple lacunar infarcts, subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy, and senile brain changes
(2) CT examination results showing interstitial changes in both lungs, calcification lesions in right lung, and sputum plug in right main bronchus
(3) Patient's symptoms of lethargy, poor appetite, vomiting, abdominal pain, muscle aches, weakness, dizziness, and trouble speaking clearly

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Continue supportive care, including intravenous fluids, oxygen therapy, and management of underlying conditions
(2) Order additional laboratory tests, including blood cultures, inflammatory markers, thyroid function tests, stool tests, and urinalysis to rule out sepsis, bacteremia, and other potential causes
(3) Consider consulting with specialists, such as neurologists, pulmonologists, and gastroenterologists, to ensure comprehensive care
(4) Monitor patient's condition closely and adjust treatment plan as necessary based on test results and clinical response

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to have unsteady gait 6 months ago, which was similar to a drunken state, and gradually worsened, but he was still able to ride a bicycle. In the past 3 months, the symptoms have further worsened, with unclear speech and dizziness when standing. The symptoms are relieved after sitting or lying down. The patient also experienced impotence but did not take it seriously. Subsequently, he developed frequent urination and urgent urination, and was diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia in another hospital and underwent surgical treatment. In order to further clarify the diagnosis, the patient came to our hospital and underwent a head CT examination. Bilateral lacunar cerebral infarction was found and he was urgently admitted to the hospital due to "unsteady gait".
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- blood test
  - Blood test: normal
  - Liver function: normal
  - Kidney function: normal
- Biochemical tests
  - Serum vitamin E level: normal
- Film degree exam
  - Head CT: Bilateral lacunar infarction
  - Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): lack of fullness of the pons and brain atrophy
- Urinary system examination
  - Bladder residual urine volume: 74ml
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: multiple system atrophy
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient complained of unsteady gait for 6 months and speech impairment accompanied by dizziness for 3 months.
2. Physical examination revealed speech impairment, unsteady gait, and reduced muscle tone in the limbs.
3. Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows lack of fullness of the pons, brain atrophy, and lacunar infarction.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: Based on the patient's clinical manifestations and brain MRI results, the patient was diagnosed with multiple system atrophy. Treatment includes improving microcirculation, nerve nutrition, and improving brain metabolism. The specific treatment plan is as follows: - Shuxuening injection 20ml, intravenous drip once a day for 7 days - Citicoline sodium injection 0.5g, intravenous drip once a day for 6 days - Adenosine disodium triphosphate 20mg, intravenous drip once a day for 6 days - Vitamin B1 tablets 10mg, oral three times a day for 7 days - Vitamin B6 tablets 10mg, oral three times a day for 7 days - Methylcobalamin tablets 0.5g, oral three times a day for 7 days After treatment, the patient's gait instability, speech disorders, and dizziness symptoms were alleviated and met the discharge criteria. When discharged, the patient was advised to continue oral medication, pay attention to rest, and avoid spicy and irritating foods.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient accidentally discovered a mass on the left side of his neck 4 years ago without obvious discomfort or other symptoms. One year ago, I started to have dull pain and discomfort on the right side of my neck, but no symptoms such as hoarseness and difficulty in swallowing. Recently, I came to the hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. A color ultrasound of the thyroid showed thickening of the left lobe and isthmus, cystic nodules in the left lobe, and uneven parenchymal echo thickening (possibly Hashimoto's inflammation). The patient was admitted to the hospital after being diagnosed as a "thyroid mass" in the outpatient clinic. Since the onset of the disease, the patient's mental state, diet, sleep, weight and defecation have been normal.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Color ultrasound (2021-02-15): Thickening of the left lobe and isthmus of the thyroid gland, cystic nodules in the left lobe (TI-RADS category 2), and uneven parenchymal echo thickening (possibly Hashimoto's inflammation).
- New coronavirus RNA (2021-02-18): negative.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Middle-aged women with neck mass for more than 4 years and neck pain and discomfort for more than 1 year.
2. Physical examination revealed grade II enlargement of the left lobe of the thyroid gland with slight tenderness.
3. Color ultrasound showed thickening of the left lobe and isthmus of the thyroid gland, cystic nodules, and uneven parenchymal echo thickening.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient required surgical treatment because of pain in the neck mass and Hashimoto's thyroiditis, which are high risk factors for thyroid cancer. On February 19, 2021, left thyroid lobe and mass resection + recurrent laryngeal nerve exploration were performed. During the operation, it was found that the left lobe of the thyroid gland was diffusely swollen, hard, adherent to surrounding muscles, and had several cystic masses, the largest being approximately 0.5*0.3*0.4cm. The postoperative diagnosis was Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Lump in the neck for over 4 years
(2) Neck pain for more than a year, dull and discomforting, constant, and worsened by turning head or bending neck

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Color ultrasound (2021-02-15): Thickening of the left lobe and isthmus of the thyroid gland, cystic nodules in the left lobe (TI-RADS category 2), and uneven parenchymal echo thickening (possibly Hashimoto's inflammation)
(2) Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) of the thyroid nodule: No abnormality
(3) Thyroid function test (TFT): No abnormality
(4) Complete blood count (CBC): No abnormality

#Diagnosis#
Hashimoto's thyroiditis with thyroid nodules

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Color ultrasound results showing thickening of the left lobe and isthmus of the thyroid gland, cystic nodules in the left lobe, and uneven parenchymal echo thickening, which are consistent with Hashimoto's inflammation
(2) Patient's symptoms of neck pain and lump in the neck, which are consistent with thyroiditis and nodules

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Thyroid hormone replacement therapy to manage Hashimoto's thyroiditis
(2) Surgical consultation to discuss the possibility of removing the thyroid nodule, depending on the results of the surgical consultation and further evaluation

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed left limb weakness in the morning of the same day, which was not relieved after rest. He had no symptoms such as headache, fever, nausea, and vomiting. His mental state and appetite were good, his stool was dry, and his urine was normal.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine:
  - Immediate blood sugar: 8.4mmol/L
- Electrocardiogram:
  - Sinus rhythm
  - Normal cardiac axis
  - Abnormal T wave
- Film degree exam:
  - Neck vascular ultrasound: sclerotic plaque formation in the right common carotid artery
  - Head CT: right lateral paraventricular infarction
  - Brain MRI: demyelinating changes in the white matter of the brain, lacunar infarction in the right basal ganglia, bilateral paraventricular, parietal and frontal lobes
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Cerebral infarction; very high risk of hypertension grade 3; carotid artery sclerosis plaque formation; esophageal cancer after radiotherapy
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Previous history of radiotherapy for esophageal cancer, long-term history of hypertension, and smoking history.
2. Left limb weakness for 1 day.
3. Physical examination revealed high blood pressure, decreased muscle strength in the left limb, and decreased touch and pain perception.
4. Auxiliary examinations showed an immediate increase in blood sugar, abnormal T wave of the electrocardiogram, and cervical vascular ultrasound, head CT, and MRI all suggested cerebral infarction.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: Anti-platelet aggregation, improvement of circulation, blood pressure control, brain protection, statins and acid suppression treatment are given. After 2 weeks of hospitalization, his condition stabilized and his left limb weakness improved significantly.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Left limb weakness for one day, feeling of heaviness in the left arm and leg, making it difficult to move them
(2) No numbness, tingling, or other symptoms such as headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, tinnitus, or visual disturbances

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Body temperature: 36.9℃, Pulse: 108 beats/min, Breathing: 22 breaths/min, Blood pressure: 177/107mmHg
(2) Muscle strength of the left limb: grade 4, Reflexes: Babinski sign is negative bilaterally
(3) Complete blood count (CBC): no abnormalities
(4) Electrolyte panel: no abnormalities
(5) Renal function tests: no abnormalities
(6) MRI: demyelinating changes in the white matter of the brain, lacunar infarction in the right basal ganglia, bilateral paraventricular, parietal and frontal lobes
(7) Neck vascular ultrasound: sclerotic plaque formation in the right common carotid artery

#Diagnosis#
Lacunar infarction in the right basal ganglia, likely caused by cerebrovascular disease

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) MRI findings of lacunar infarction in the right basal ganglia and demyelinating changes in the white matter of the brain
(2) Neck vascular ultrasound findings of sclerotic plaque formation in the right common carotid artery
(3) Patient's symptoms of left limb weakness and medical history of hypertension

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medications to control blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and platelet aggregation
(2) Lifestyle changes such as a healthy diet, regular exercise, and stress management to reduce the risk of further vascular events
(3) Referral to a physical therapist to help regain strength and mobility in the left limb

    - HBV DNA: 无异常

#Diagnosis#
Hepatitis B-related liver dysfunction

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) History of hepatitis B infection
(2) Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST) and total bilirubin

#Treatment Plan#

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed right-sided chest pain without obvious triggers, accompanied by dry cough. The symptoms worsened when coughing and taking deep breaths. Low fever occurred, with a maximum body temperature of 37.9°C. Fever occurred in the afternoon, and the body temperature was normal in the morning. No chills, fever, or sweating. He went to a local hospital and was diagnosed with "pneumonia". He received intravenous infusion treatment, but the symptoms were not relieved. A week ago, I developed dyspnea and chest tightness, accompanied by fatigue, night sweats, and loss of appetite. The chest pain was relieved, but the cough was not relieved. Therefore, he came to our hospital for treatment. He was diagnosed as "pleural effusion" in the outpatient department and was admitted to the hospital.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Imaging examination:
- Chest X-ray: A large patch of increased density shadow was seen in the lung field below the second intercostal space on the right side, with a blurred upper edge and the mediastinum shifted to the left. This indicates a large amount of fluid in the right pleural cavity.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Massive pleural effusion on the right side (tuberculous)
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Acute onset, young male.
2. Chest pain and cough lasted for half a month, and dyspnea and chest tightness developed recently.
3. Physical examination revealed that the respiratory motility was weakened on the right side, enhanced on the left side, the vibrato was weakened on the right side, and the breath sounds in the right lung disappeared.
4. Chest X-ray showed a large amount of pleural effusion on the right side.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Chest pain (dull ache, right-sided, worsened by coughing or deep breathing)
(2) Cough (dry, worsened by lying down or taking deep breaths)
(3) Difficulty breathing
(4) Chest tightness
(5) Low-grade fever (maximum 37.9°C)
(6) Night sweats
(7) Loss of appetite
(8) Weight loss
(9) Fatigue

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest examination: weakened respiratory motion on the right side, enhanced on the left side, widened intercostal space, weakened speech tremor on the right side, and no twisting sensation or pleural friction sensation.
(2) Chest X-ray: large patch of increased density shadow in the lung field below the second intercostal space on the right side, with a blurred upper edge and the mediastinum shifted to the left, indicating a large amount of fluid in the right pleural cavity.
(3) Thoracentesis and pleural fluid analysis: pending results
(4) CT scan of the chest: pending results

#Diagnosis#
Malignant pleural effusion (likely due to lung cancer or metastatic disease)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Chest X-ray findings indicating a large amount of fluid in the right pleural cavity
(2) Symptoms consistent with malignant pleural effusion, including chest pain, cough, difficulty breathing, and weight loss
(3) Pending results of thoracentesis and pleural fluid analysis, which may reveal malignant cells or other signs of malignancy
(4) Pending results of CT scan of the chest, which may reveal a primary tumor or metastatic disease

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Thoracentesis and pleural fluid analysis to determine the nature of the fluid and identify any malignant cells
(2) CT scan of the chest to evaluate for primary tumor or metastatic disease
(3) Supportive care, including oxygen therapy, pain management, and management of cough and difficulty breathing
(4) Referral to oncology for further evaluation and treatment if malignant pleural effusion is confirmed

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient went to the emergency department of our hospital six months ago due to dizziness. His blood pressure was measured at 192/123mmHg. He was discharged after antihypertensive treatment. After discharge, he failed to take medication regularly and monitor his blood pressure. In the past 4 days, I developed low back pain, accompanied by numbness and weakness in both lower limbs, without chest pain, chest tightness, palpitations, shortness of breath and other symptoms. When he visited the emergency department again, his blood pressure was 200/122mmHg, and CTA of the thoracoabdominal aorta showed no abnormalities. After treatment, his blood pressure was still high and he was hospitalized for further diagnosis and treatment. The patient had a good spirit and appetite, snored at night, occasionally had apnea, and had no obvious weight change.

- Blood routine, myocardial enzymes, renal function electrolytes, coagulation function, D-dimer, amylase: no obvious abnormalities
- Electrocardiogram, thoracoabdominal aorta CTA: no obvious abnormalities
- blood lipids
  - Triglycerides: 2.31mmol/L (increased)
  - HDL cholesterol: 0.71mmol/L (lower)
  - LDL cholesterol: 3.42mmol/L (increased)
- Liver function, ACTH, blood cortisol rhythm, urinary cortisol, four items before blood transfusion, three items of thyroid function, homocysteine, formaldehyde supine and upright test, 24-hour urine sodium and potassium, plasma and 24 hours Urinary MNS, urinary microalbumin, urinary microalbumin to creatinine, COVID-19 antibodies: no obvious abnormalities
- Color Doppler Ultrasound
  - Cardiac color Doppler ultrasound: No obvious abnormality found
  - Double renal vascular color ultrasound: no obvious abnormality
  - Color Doppler Ultrasound of Neck Vessels: No obvious abnormality found
  - Abdominal color ultrasound: fatty liver
- CT examination
  - Enhanced CT of head + lungs + adrenal glands: paranasal sinusitis, a few fibroproliferative lesions in the lungs, and small cysts in the liver
  - CT of brain and bilateral adrenal glands: no abnormalities found
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Severe sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome
2. Severe nocturnal hypoxemia
3. Secondary hypertension grade 3 high risk group
4. Hyperlipidemia
5. Fatty liver
6. Small cysts in the liver
7. Paranasal sinusitis
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure was >140/90 mmHg at rest for many times, reaching the diagnostic criteria for hypertension. The cause is unknown and further examination is required.
2. Obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea syndrome? : The patient is obese, snoring at night, accompanied by apnea, combined with extremely high blood pressure and hypoxemia, considering whether this syndrome exists.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to the hospital, he was given oxygen inhalation and sodium bicarbonate fluid infusion according to the results of blood gas analysis. Sodium nitroprusside was used for antihypertensive treatment. Further examinations included blood lipids, liver function, thyroid function, etc. After consultation with the otolaryngology department, he was diagnosed with severe sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome and nocturnal hypoxemia. Atorvastatin calcium was given to regulate blood lipids, nasal positive pressure ventilation therapy to improve apnea, and antihypertensive drugs. After 7 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms improved, blood pressure was 147/92 mmHg, and he was discharged from the hospital.

Suxiao Jiuxin Pills can alleviate the symptoms, accompanied by a decrease in activity tolerance. I recently developed unprovoked pinprick-like pain in the precordial area. doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Chest tightness and pain for about a year, worsened over the past two months
(2) Decreased activity tolerance
(3) Shortness of breath, especially with exertion
(4) Fatigue

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Physical examination: clear breath sounds, normal heart rate and rhythm, no abnormal murmurs
(2) ECG: sinus bradycardia, T wave changes
(3) Echocardiography: EF 46%, segmental dyskinesia of left ventricular myocardium, slightly larger left heart ratio, decreased left ventricular diastolic function, degenerative changes of aortic valve with mild regurgitation, widening of aortic sinus and ascending aorta
(4) Blood biochemistry: NT-ProBNP 1254.30pg/ml, cTnI and CK-MB within normal limits

#Diagnosis#
Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of chest tightness and pain, decreased activity tolerance, shortness of breath, and fatigue
(2) Echocardiography results showing EF 46%, segmental dyskinesia of left ventricular myocardium, and decreased left ventricular diastolic function
(3) Elevated NT-ProBNP level indicating heart failure or cardiac dysfunction

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medications: beta blocker to slow down heart rate and reduce workload on heart, ACE inhibitor to lower blood pressure and reduce strain on heart
(2) Lifestyle changes: reduce sodium intake, increase physical activity levels, manage stress levels
(3) Further testing: cardiac catheterization, stress echocardiography, and 24-hour Holter monitoring to evaluate coronary arteries, heart function, and rhythm.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: myasthenia gravis
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient presented with diplopia, drooping of the left eye and face, fluctuating symptoms, positive fatigue test, and positive myasthenia gravis antibody spectrum. Myasthenia gravis was considered.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Diplopia (fluctuating, worse in the evening, and more pronounced when looking to the sides or upwards)

(3) Head discomfort (dull, heavy sensation, mostly on the left side)
(4) Fatigue
(5) Cold (cough and nasal congestion)

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Brain MRI+MRA: basilar artery, bilateral posterior cerebral arteriosclerosis, bilateral embryonic posterior cerebral arteries
(2) Electromyography (EMG): No obvious abnormality
(3) Laboratory tests (autoimmune disorders): All negative
(4) Brain MRA: basilar artery, bilateral posterior cerebral arteriosclerosis, bilateral embryonic posterior cerebral arteries

#Diagnosis#
Ischemic cranial neuropathy

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of diplopia, drooping of the left eye and face, and head discomfort
(2) MRI and MRA findings of basilar artery arteriosclerosis and bilateral posterior cerebral arteriosclerosis
(3) EMG and laboratory test results ruling out other potential causes

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Conservative measures to improve blood flow to the brain, including medications to control blood pressure
(2) Lifestyle changes to improve cardiovascular health, such as regular exercise, a healthy diet, stress management, getting enough sleep, and staying hydrated

reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A 55-year-old man suffered from fatigue and yellow urine.
2. Physical examination: The abdomen is soft and non-tender, the liver and spleen are not palpable, and there is no percussion pain in the liver area.
3. Medical history: Long-term recurring headaches and intermittent use of painkillers.

After a week of active treatment, the patient's symptoms improved and he was discharged.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Fatigue for 5 days
(2) Dark yellow urine for 5 days
(3) Epigastric pain for 1 month
(4) Headaches for 3 years

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 4.77×10^9/L, NEU# 3.04×10^9/L, HGB 112g/L
(2) Liver Function Tests (LFTs): ALT 297U/L, AST 83U/L, TBIL 34.4μmol/L, GGT 243.00IU/L, DBIL 7.24μmol/L, TP 68.20g/L, ALB 40.10g/L
(3) Urinalysis: No abnormalities

#Diagnosis#
Drug-induced liver injury

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, GGT) and bilirubin levels (TBIL, DBIL) indicating liver damage
(2) History of taking "pain-removing tablets" which may be the causative agent
(3) Exclusion of other potential causes of liver dysfunction (e.g., viral hepatitis, autoimmune hepatitis)

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Stop taking "pain-removing tablets" immediately to prevent further liver damage
(2) Monitor liver function closely with repeat laboratory tests and regular check-ins
(3) Consider alternative pain management options (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen, tramadol, gabapentin)
(4) Perform additional tests (e.g., drug-induced liver injury panel, liver ultrasound, liver biopsy) to confirm diagnosis and assess extent of liver damage

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Edema in both lower limbs for a month, more severe on the left side, accompanied by pain in the left lower limb
(2) Cough, expectoration, chest tightness, and asthma for 17 days, worsened by physical activity
(3) Shortness of breath and difficulty breathing, especially after physical activity
(4) Wheezing sounds when breathing out

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest examination: thick breath sounds in both lungs, a small amount of moist rales at the left lung base
(2) Heart rate: 92 beats/min, rhythm was regular, heart sounds were low and dull, P2 was elevated, no valve murmur
(3) Abdomen: flat, active bowel sounds, soft, liver was 4 cm below the ribs and was soft, with distension and discomfort
(4) Edema: moderate pitting edema in both lower limbs, heavier on the left side
(5) White blood cell count: 14*10^9/L, Neutrophil ratio: 82%

(8) Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm, left axis deviation, ST segment depression in leads V1-V5, T wave inversion
(9) Lower extremity vascular ultrasound: lower left superficial femoral vein and popliteal vein thrombosis

#Diagnosis#
Pulmonary embolism with right atrial emboli, double pneumonia, and deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Chest CT with contrast showing pulmonary embolism, right atrial emboli, and double pneumonia lesions
(2) Lower extremity vascular ultrasound showing lower left superficial femoral vein and popliteal vein thrombosis
(3) Clinical symptoms and physical examination findings consistent with pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Anticoagulation therapy to prevent further clotting
(2) Antibiotics to treat the pneumonia
(3) Oxygen therapy and other supportive care to manage symptoms
(4) Admission to the hospital for further treatment and monitoring
(5) Further testing, such as an echocardiogram, to assess the function of the heart and evaluate the severity of the pulmonary embolism

(5) Cardiac rehabilitation program to improve overall cardiovascular health

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient's physical examination 11 years ago revealed that his fasting blood sugar was 12.4 mmol/L, and he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He started taking Novolone 2 mg three times a day and Rosiglitazone 4 mg once a day, along with diet and exercise. In the past two years, rosiglitazone was discontinued due to shortage, and Novolone treatment was maintained, with fasting blood sugar controlled at 7-8mmol/L. In the past two months, due to irregular medication, he developed blurred vision, dizziness, dry mouth and polydipsia, and lost 7 kilograms in weight. The random blood sugar in the outpatient department was 18.8mmol/L, so he was admitted to the hospital.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Type 2 diabetes
2. Diabetic peripheral neuropathy
3. Diabetic nephropathy
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient had an 11-year history of elevated blood sugar. Recently, he developed numbness and pain in the extremities of his hands and feet, blurred vision in both eyes, dizziness, nausea, dry mouth, polydipsia, and weight loss. Auxiliary examinations showed hyperglycemia, elevated glycated hemoglobin, elevated C-peptide and urinary trace protein, elevated triglycerides, and abnormal Q waves on the electrocardiogram.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient underwent a comprehensive examination after admission, and diabetic retinopathy was ruled out by ophthalmology consultation. Due to poor blood sugar control, insulin therapy was started, and the blood sugar was basically stable after adjusting the dosage. Oral acarbose is administered to control postprandial blood sugar. Intravenous administration of ginkgo leaf extract and lipoic acid improves microcirculation and neurological symptoms. Abnormal Q waves on the electrocardiogram should be considered as coronary heart disease, and coronary CT should be ruled out. Atorvastatin was given for hyperlipidemia and fatty liver. Urinary trace protein increased, and oral pancreatic kallikreinogenase improved microcirculation. After 11 days of hospitalization, his blood sugar stabilized and he was discharged.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Numbness in hands and feet, especially the tips of fingers and toes
(2) Blurred vision in both eyes
(3) Weakness in hands
(4) Difficulty with balance and coordination
(5) Fatigue
(6) Dizziness
(7) Mood changes
(8) Polydipsia
(9) Polyuria
(10) Weight loss (7 kg in 2 months)

(1) Complete Blood Count: slightly low hemoglobin level, elevated red blood cell count

(4) Urinalysis: protein in urine, concentrated urine
(5) Renal Function Test: impaired kidney function (GFR 60 mL/min)

#Diagnosis#
Diabetic neuropathy and diabetic nephropathy due to uncontrolled type 2 diabetes

(1) Symptoms of numbness, weakness, and pain in hands and feet, as well as blurred vision, fatigue, and dizziness
(2) Elevated hemoglobin A1c level indicating poor blood sugar control
(3) Impaired kidney function and protein in urine indicating diabetic nephropathy
(4) Nerve conduction study results consistent with diabetic neuropathy

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Adjust diabetes medication regimen to improve blood sugar control
(2) Lifestyle changes: healthy diet, regular exercise, stress management, and adequate rest
(3) Medications to manage nerve pain and numbness
(4) Medications to support kidney function
(5) Regular monitoring of blood sugar levels and kidney function
(6) Follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, stable angina pectoris, cardiac function class II (NYHA classification), hypertension class 3 (very high risk).
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient had a history of hypertension and developed typical chest pain symptoms. Coronary artery CT showed lesions in the left anterior descending artery.
2. No obvious abnormalities were found in the physical examination, and no obvious abnormalities were found in the electrocardiogram. The dynamic electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm and premature beats.
3. A 20-year history of hypertension. The blood pressure control status is not clear. According to the degree of blood pressure increase, it is classified as level 3, which is extremely high risk.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Intermittent chest pain for more than a month, worsening in the past two days
(2) Feeling of pressure or tightness in the precordial area, triggered by exertion and relieved by rest
(3) Dizziness, occurring at the same time as the chest pain

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Coronary artery CT scan: mixed plaques in the proximal left anterior descending artery with mild luminal narrowing
(2) Electrocardiogram (ECG): no obvious abnormalities
(3) Holter ECG: normal heart rhythm, premature atrial and ventricular contractions
(4) Blood pressure: 160/100 mmHg
(5) Troponin level: elevated

#Diagnosis#
Unstable Angina

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms of intermittent chest pain and dizziness, triggered by exertion and relieved by rest, are consistent with unstable angina.
(2) The coronary artery CT scan shows mixed plaques in the proximal left anterior descending artery with mild luminal narrowing, which supports the diagnosis of unstable angina.
(3) The elevated troponin level suggests possible myocardial damage.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medication: anti-platelet agents, beta blockers, and nitrates to manage symptoms and reduce the risk of further cardiac events.
(2) Lifestyle modifications: stress reduction, regular exercise, and a healthy diet to improve overall cardiovascular health.
(3) Further evaluation and treatment: consultation with a cardiologist to discuss the need for further testing, such as cardiac catheterization, and potential interventional procedures, such as angioplasty or stenting.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient experienced squeezing pain in the precordium area without obvious triggers, which did not radiate to the shoulders and back. The symptoms worsened after activity and were not relieved by rest. Three hours ago, the symptoms worsened, accompanied by shortness of breath, but no dyspnea or abdominal pain, so he came to the hospital for treatment.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood, urine and stool routine: no abnormality
- Myocardial enzymes and myocardial infarction: higher than normal values
- Electrocardiogram: left bundle branch block, dorsal ST segment elevation in leads V1-V6, suggesting acute myocardial infarction.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Acute myocardial infarction
2. Heart failure
3. Hypertension grade 2 (high risk)
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. An elderly male with precordial pain, elevated cardiac enzymes, and changes in the ST segment of the electrocardiogram is consistent with the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.
2. A 5-year history of hypertension, blood pressure of 160/90mmHg, and organ damage, which is consistent with the diagnosis of hypertension level 2 (high risk).
reference_diagnosis.treatment: An electrocardiogram was performed immediately after admission and acute myocardial infarction was diagnosed. After emergency coronary angiography, 100% occlusion of the left main trunk was found. Thrombus aspiration, balloon dilation, and intracoronary administration (tirofiban, etc.) were performed to restore blood flow. Postoperative treatment was with isosorbide dinitrate, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol and nifedipine. Symptoms of heart failure occurred the next day, and she was given diuretic treatment with furosemide and neoactivin, and her condition became stable. Coronary angiography before discharge showed smooth blood flow.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Squeezing pain in the precordium area that has lasted for 10 hours and worsened over the past 3 hours
(2) Shortness of breath

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Electrocardiogram: left bundle branch block, dorsal ST segment elevation in leads V1-V6, suggesting acute myocardial infarction
(2) Cardiac Enzyme tests: higher than normal values

#Diagnosis#
Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Electrocardiogram showing left bundle branch block and dorsal ST segment elevation in leads V1-V6, indicating acute myocardial infarction
(2) Elevated cardiac enzyme levels, further supporting the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medications: aspirin, thrombolytic agents, beta blockers, ACE inhibitors or ARBs, and statins
(2) Interventional procedures: percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to open up the blocked coronary artery using a balloon angioplasty and/or stenting, or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery if PCI is not possible
(3) Cardiac care unit (CCU) admission for close monitoring
(4) Lifestyle modifications: quit smoking, dietary changes, increased physical activity, and stress reduction

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient suddenly had slurred speech and inability to move his left limb while drinking alcohol 1.5 hours ago. He had no symptoms such as headache, dizziness, or difficulty swallowing. An emergency brain CT examination showed no abnormalities, and he was diagnosed with "cerebrovascular disease" and admitted to the Department of Neurology.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Brain CT: no obvious abnormalities.
- Brain MRI: shows acute or subacute ischemic infarction in part of the right cerebral hemisphere.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Cerebral infarction (small artery occlusion type)
2. Hypertension (normal level)
3. Hyperlipidemia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Past history of hypertension.
2. Sudden slurred speech and inability to move the left limb.
3. Physical examination revealed that the nasolabial groove on the left side was slightly shallow and the muscle strength of the left limb was weakened.
4. No abnormality was found in brain CT, and brain magnetic resonance showed acute or subacute ischemic infarction.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
- Provide ECG monitoring and blood oxygen saturation monitoring.
- Alteplase 54mg intravenous thrombolytic treatment.
- Dual antiplatelet aggregation drug therapy.
- Drug treatment such as edaravone, butylphthalide, and rabeprazole.
- Ginkgolide injection promotes blood circulation and removes blood stasis.
- Rosuvastatin controls blood lipids and stabilizes plaques.
- The patient's blood pressure is under ideal control and no antihypertensive drugs are currently being used.
- After 10 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms improved. When he was discharged from the hospital, his speech was clear and his left limbs were flexible.

(1) Sudden onset of slurred speech

(2) Brain MRI: acute or subacute ischemic infarction in part of the right cerebral hemisphere
(3) CBC: no abnormalities
(4) Electrolyte panel: no abnormalities
(5) Renal function tests: no abnormalities

#Diagnosis#
Ischemic stroke

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Sudden onset of neurological symptoms, including slurred speech and left limb weakness
(2) Brain MRI findings of acute or subacute ischemic infarction in part of the right cerebral hemisphere

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Hospital admission for further management and monitoring
(2) Control of blood pressure and management of hypertension
(3) Supportive care to prevent complications such as pneumonia or deep vein thrombosis
(4) Evaluation to identify the underlying cause of the stroke, including ECG, echocardiogram, and carotid artery ultrasound
(5) Consideration of medications to prevent further strokes, such as antiplatelet agents or anticoagulants

(3) Presence of risk factors such as hypertension and carotid artery plaque formation

(4) Neurological rehabilitation to help regain strength and function in the left limb
(5) Regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient ate a high-fat diet after dinner on January 23, 2022, and felt upper abdominal pain from 9 a.m. the next day. The pain was concentrated in the left upper abdomen, persistent and severe, accompanied by nausea and vomiting, and vomiting did not relieve the pain. There was no radiating pain in the left lower back, acid reflux, heartburn, hematemesis, melena, or fever, chills, or jaundice. No treatment was given, and he came to the emergency room because his symptoms worsened. CT examination on admission showed pancreatitis with peripheral effusion and fatty liver. The patient had no dizziness, fatigue, palpitation, chest tightness, chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, or expectoration. He had normal urine, no flatulence and defecation, and no significant change in weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine: WBC count 15.14x10^9/L
- Electrolytes: basically normal
- Blood lipids: Triglycerides 9.44mmol/L
- Liver and kidney function: normal
- Procalcitonin: normal
- Blood sugar: normal
- Imaging: Upper abdominal CT showed pancreatitis with peripheral exudation and fatty liver
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Acute pancreatitis hyperlipidemia type
2. Systemic inflammatory response syndrome
3. Fatty liver
4. Hyperlipidemia
5. Hypoalbuminemia
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours. The medical history, symptoms, physical examination and auxiliary examination results (especially upper abdominal CT and white blood cell count) supported the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and fatty liver.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient's abdominal pain worsened and he developed high fever, up to 39°C. ECG, blood pressure, and blood oxygen monitoring were performed, and low-flow oxygen inhalation was performed. Omeprazole was used to suppress acid, low molecular weight heparin was used to lower lipids, somatostatin was used to suppress pancreatic enzyme secretion, fluids were replenished to maintain water and electrolyte balance, and moxifloxacin was used for anti-infection treatment. The patient recovered and was discharged from the hospital on January 30, 2022. When discharged, she had no fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or abdominal distension, and had normal gas and bowel movements.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours
(2) Nausea and vomiting, with vomit consisting of food
(3) Bloating
(4) Left upper abdominal tenderness

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) CT scan: pancreatitis with peripheral effusion and fatty liver
(2) WBC count: 15.14x10^9/L
(3) Triglycerides: 9.44mmol/L
(4) Liver function: normal
(5) Abdominal ultrasound: no abnormalities
(6) Amylase test: no abnormalities

#Diagnosis#
Acute pancreatitis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of upper abdominal distension and pain, nausea, and vomiting
(2) CT scan results showing pancreatitis with peripheral effusion and fatty liver
(3) Elevated WBC count and triglyceride levels
(4) Normal liver function and abdominal ultrasound results

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Fluid management: intravenous fluids to manage dehydration and electrolyte imbalances
(2) Pain management: pain medication to manage abdominal pain
(3) NPO (Nothing by Mouth): avoiding eating and drinking to give the pancreas a chance to rest and recover
(4) Dietary changes: avoiding high-fat foods, increasing intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, and reducing sugar and refined carbohydrates
(5) Lipid-lowering therapy: medication to lower triglyceride levels
(6) Lifestyle modifications: losing weight, increasing physical activity, quitting smoking, and reducing alcohol intake
(7) Follow-up care: regular check-ups and blood tests to monitor triglyceride levels and liver function

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient reported that he began to experience fatigue and weakness 2 years ago, and his symptoms gradually worsened. During this period, no skin purpura, fever, chills, bleeding symptoms (gum bleeding, nose bleeding, blood in urine or stool), nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, etc. occurred. He was diagnosed with "essential thrombocythemia" in a local tertiary hospital. He received interferon injections and oral medication, and his symptoms improved. In the past half month, bright red bleeding occurred after defecation, about 30 ml each time, and stopped on its own without constipation or diarrhea. He came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. He was diagnosed as "essential thrombocythemia and mixed hemorrhoids" in the outpatient department and was admitted to the hospital.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine:
  - White blood cell count: 8.5*10^9/L
  - Neutrophil ratio: 61.60%
  - Lymphocyte ratio: 31.3%
  - Number of neutrophils: 5.23*10^9/L
  -Number of lymphocytes: 2.66*10^9/L
  - Number of monocytes: 0.54*10^9/L
  - Eosinophil count: 0.09*10^9/L
  - Red blood cell count: 3.68*10^12/L
  - Hemoglobin: 119g/L
  - Hematocrit: 34.8%
  - Platelet count: 651*10^9/L
  - Platelet density: 0.454%
- Coagulation:
  - Prothrombin time: 11.2 seconds
  - International normalized ratio: 0.89
  - Partially activated prothrombin time: 30.3 seconds
  - Fibrinogen: 2.67g/L
  - Thrombin time: 15.3 seconds
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Essential thrombocythemia
2. Mixed hemorrhoids
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A middle-aged woman with chronic onset, long-term fatigue and weakness.
2. Diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia 2 years ago, symptoms improved after treatment.
3. Recently, bright red bleeding after defecation stopped on its own.
4. Skin tags were found during perianal examination, but no tumors were felt during rectal examination.
5. Routine blood test showed a significant increase in platelet count.
6. Coagulation function test results were basically normal.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent a comprehensive examination and was given traditional Chinese medicine fumigation, topical hemorrhoid ointment and hemorrhoid suppository treatment, as well as hemostatic drugs. As post-defecation bleeding persisted and conservative treatment was ineffective, surgical treatment was decided. Under spinal anesthesia, hemorrhoid internal ligation and external removal, anal sphincter dilation and hemorrhoid injection were performed. Postoperative bleeding stopped and the patient recovered and was discharged.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Fatigue and weakness for 2 years, gradually worsening
(2) Bleeding after defecation for half a month, with bright red blood, 30 ml each time, stopping on its own without constipation or diarrhea

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete blood count: white blood cell count 8.5*10^9/L, platelet count 651*10^9/L, hemoglobin 119g/L, hematocrit 34.8%
(2) Liver function tests: normal
(3) Colonoscopy: no abnormalities
(4) Iron studies: iron 4.5 μmol/L, ferritin 12 ng/mL, transferrin saturation 10%
(5) Stool tests: fecal occult blood test positive, stool calprotectin 150 μg/g
(6) Endoscopy with biopsy: mild chronic inflammation in the gastric mucosa, no evidence of malignancy or dysplasia
(7) Capsule endoscopy: multiple areas of mucosal inflammation and ulceration in the small intestine
(8) MRI enterography: thickening of the small intestine wall
(9) Fecal biomarkers: lactoferrin and S100A12 elevated

#Diagnosis#
Crohn's disease

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of fatigue, weakness, and bleeding after defecation
(2) Abnormal iron studies and stool tests indicating inflammation in the gut
(3) Endoscopy with biopsy showing mild chronic inflammation in the gastric mucosa
(4) Capsule endoscopy and MRI enterography showing inflammation and ulceration in the small intestine
(5) Elevated fecal biomarkers indicating active inflammation in the gut

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medications: aminosalicylates, corticosteroids, and immunomodulators to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms
(2) Lifestyle changes: dietary modifications, stress management, and smoking cessation to manage symptoms and prevent complications

Unconsciousness, not eating or drinking, dry stools, and urinary incontinence.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Septic shock, sepsis, pulmonary infection, urinary tract infection, acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, cerebellar atrophy
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Fever, confusion, body temperature up to 39°C, long-term bed rest, nausea and profuse sweating.
2. Abnormal blood gas analysis, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated PCT.
3. He has a history of cerebellar atrophy for more than 20 years, has been bedridden for a long time, and cannot take care of himself.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, routine sepsis care, special monitoring, oxygen inhalation, and blood glucose monitoring were implemented. Anti-infective treatment includes Xuebijing, vasopressor drugs, phlegm-reducing agents, blood-activating agents, neurotrophic agents, myocardial nutrients, acid-suppressing and stomach-protecting agents, fluid rehydration, and blood sugar control. Antibiotic therapy was adjusted based on bacterial culture results. After treatment, the patient's condition improved, his blood count was normal, and he no longer had fever. He was discharged from the hospital on March 6.
